Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Cybersecurity Research in a Multidisciplinary Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award establishes a new Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Old Dominion University. The REU Site is led by faculty from the Center for Cybersecurity Education and Research (CCSER) at the university. CCSER includes faculty from a large number of departments and colleges across the university that can provide a range of multidisciplinary research projects that focus on problems that are important and attractive to undergraduates. The REU Site will host 10 students from across the nation to conduct research during the summer with faculty mentors. The students will live in the Cybersecurity Living and Learning Community associated with CCSER. The project plans to recruit a diverse cohort of undergraduate students each summer, including students from under-represented minorities, women, and veterans. In addition to their research activities, the students will participate in other professional development activities that will prepare them for entering the computing workforce and for possible futures as researchers.

The REU site is led by faculty mentors from the Center for Cybersecurity Education and Research. The faculty of the Center have significant research expertise and offer state-of-the-art facilities that should provide a compelling research experience to undergraduates. This REU site offers unique multidisciplinary learning and research opportunities for undergraduate students in the inherently multidisciplinary cybersecurity discipline. Students will explore topics across multiple disciplines including networks, machine learning, decision science, sociology, criminal justice, and philosophy. Students will be advised by a multidisciplinary mentoring committee with faculty from at least 3 different areas. This approach should promote multidisciplinary collaborations among students and increase their interest toward careers in the important field of cybersecurity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cybersecurity is a priority area of national need. As a multidisciplinary field, cybersecurity requires that the professionals have knowledge and skills in various disciplines. This REU program has established a multidisciplinary learning and research environment for undergraduate students, to explore a variety of cybersecurity topics across multiple disciplines. Students have worked on multidisciplinary REU projects advised by a multidisciplinary faculty team and were trained to master research methodologies and obtain research experiences. During the REU program, to prepare students to build a multidisciplinary cybersecurity career and pursue graduate study, various activities have been organized including seminars, talks, graduate study panels, career panels, field trips to the Navy Cyber Defense Operation Command (NCDOC) and the Norfolk Naval Base.

The program has been successful for cybersecurity workforce development, and broadening participation in STEM fields from underrepresented groups, with a majority of REU participants to be underrepresented minority or female student.  The three year program supported total 30 undergraduate students from institutions across the nation to conduct cutting-edge cybersecurity research with faculty mentors at Old Dominion University (ODU) for ten weeks during summers from 2017 to 2019. The REU students have also actively participated in outreach to the local community, and organized REU panels in annual Cybersecurity summer camps hosted at ODU to middle and high school students. The research findings of REU students have been disseminated through venues of publications and talks. The REU students have published twelve papers, including two journal articles in the Journal of Information Security and Applications and the American Journal of Criminal Justice, as well as ten papers in conference proceedings. Moreover, one REU student, Mr. Nick Liu, in summer 2018, received the Best Student Research Paper Award in the Annual Conference of International Association for Computer Information Systems (IACIS) 2019.  Another REU student, Ms. Jahmelia Atkinson, in summer 2019, received the second place in the undergraduate poster presentation in 2020 Emerging Researchers National Conference in STEM.
